p: Fur-bearing mammals are considered to be particularly sensitive to habitat loss and fragmentation [ 1– 4]. Their habitats have been affected especially by major changes that are incurred through human activities, such as forest harvesting and agricultural development [ 5, 6]. Climate change could further modify or reduce the quality of available habitats [ 7, 8]. Yet climate change and anthropogenic disturbances such as forest harvesting may also increase access to new territories by modifying biotic and abiotic factors that otherwise would limit a species’ potential to utilize a territory [ 9]. Given that climate change and anthropogenic disturbances occur over long periods of time, resulting in complex cumulative impacts, they are often difficult to understand and to document [ 10, 11].
